title: Tear gas fills streets of Hong Kong as thousands of protesters defy face mask ban
text:
Thousands came out for the unsanctioned rallies, with tensions only rising after four months of mass protests - Getty Images AsiaPac

Tens of thousands of masked Hong Kong citizens braved torrential rain, tear gas and arrest on Sunday as they marched through the streets of the global financial hub in open defiance of a government ban on face masks.

The crowds at the unsanctioned rallies included families with children, old people and pregnant women, in a sign of the widespread public anger at the move by Carrie Lam, the city’s chief executive, to use a sweeping Emergency Regulations Ordinance to enforce a ban that many believe impairs their freedoms.

“We are suppressed by the strong government. They suppress us through a law to threaten the people to stay at home. That’s why we have to come out to voice our opinions,” said an older woman called Mrs Mak, as she sheltered under her husband’s umbrella.

“I have to come out to fight for the youngsters, because I am nearly 60. I come out because I have to support them. The future belongs to them. I want the government to hear what people are saying,” she said.

An emergency law has criminalised protesters wearing face masks Credit: Nicolas Asfouri/AFP/Getty Images More

The crowd was initially peaceful but visibly nervous, at times stopping and running backwards, after months of violent clashes between police and protesters that have resulted in multiple arrests and two live shootings.

By mid-afternoon the police had fired the first tear gas canisters at protesters erecting barricades along major routes, before pushing demonstrators back to the shopping districts of Wan Chai and Causeway Bay and making multiple arrests. Tear gas was also fired in Kowloon.

Carrie Lam had justified the introduction of the ban as a measure to restore calm to the city after months of unrest that began with a bill that could extradite people to China but has since spiraled into a wider call for democratic rights.

Some protesters lit fires to block traffic in the city centre Credit: Vincent Thian/AP More

However, many in Hong Kong believe the move has added fuel to the fire of simmering anger with the government and heavy-handed police action.

On Sunday morning, a group of pro-democracy lawmakers failed in a high court bid to seek an emergency injunction against the ban, arguing that emergency powers bypassed the legislature and contravened the city’s mini-constitution.

Sharron Fast, a Hong Kong-based lawyer warned that the use of the emergency regulation had given the chief executive an “unlimited amount of power, in which she alone can enact laws".

She added: "She has gone on record and hasn't dismissed the possibility to enact other laws with the ERO, which can include censorship laws, deportation orders, the repossession of property, and even requiring people to work."
description: Tens of thousands of masked Hong Kong citizens braved torrential rain, tear gas and arrest on Sunday as they marched through the streets of the global financial hub in open defiance of a government ban on face masks.
